night recording
night recording
2 birds,
Temp +5 C

Churring from a singing Nightjar for a constant five minutes. Listen carefully at the end of the recording and you can hear the wing beats of the bird flying off from its perch at the top of a tree. 
The habitat here is conifer plantation at the boundary of mature trees and a rough area that had previously been cleared. Recorded on a beautiful, clear and warm evening with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66 on a tripod.
Some editing of EQ around 450 Hz to reduce the sound from farm machinery and also some reduction of barking dogs below 800 Hz.

I also made two other recordings of Nightjars this evening:

XC484859

XC484860

The nightjar was singing on the top of a pole at a road in a small woods, and then chased off by another nightjar (a strange sound can be heard at the end of the sound file, probably a fight call).  
Equipment: Telinga parabola with Sennheiser ME62 microphone&K6, and Marantz PMD-620 MKII recorder.
Song from a tree starting with a very long phrase. I had just played an earlier recording, thinking it would come closer, but instead it flew away.

In flight.

recordings.type: nocturnal flight call, nocturnal flight call
recordings.rmk: Filters used :  high pass filter : 1000 kHz - 12 dB, amplify : 15dB, fade in, fade out
Nocturnal recording. Pine forest complex close to big fish complex.

**Comments**: Likely two bird singing in the recording.

**Recording modifications**: High-pass filter 1000 Hz 12 dB. Normalized (DC offset, peak amplitude to -2.0 dB). Modified using Audacity. Recorded with LG K10 2017.

**Habitat (inc. vegetation and level)**: Mixed conifer forest. Recording made in a pine stand surrounded by spruce coppice.

**Behaviour**: N/A.

**Sex (with ID cues)**: N/A.

**Weather and other conditions**: Clear and windless night.

**Comments on other birds**: N/A.

recordings.loc: Casale Poggio del Tiglio,  Viagrande, Provincia di Catania, Sicilia

recordings.rmk:
Churring sequence from a singing Nightjar. It begins by singing from a song perch a little distance away and moves closer from the seventh minute. Somewhat surprisingly there is a bird singing in the background at 22:11 and from 22:54 - I'm not sure what it is but it is perhaps a Blackcap? The habitat here is conifer plantation at the boundary of mature trees and a rough area that had previously been cleared.
Recorded on a beautiful, clear and warm evening with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66 left running. Some editing below 450 Hz to reduce farm machinery and aircraft.

I also made two other recordings of Nightjars this evening:

XC484858

XC484859

Churring sequence from a singing Nightjar. 
Listen carefully at the beginning and also at 7:11 you can hear the bird's wing beats as it flies. At the end of the recording the bird finishes its song with a wing-clapping display and a single call. The habitat here is conifer plantation at the boundary of mature trees and a rough area that had previously been cleared.
Recorded on a beautiful, clear and warm evening with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66 left running. Some editing of EQ below 700 Hz to reduce the sound of farm machinery.


I also made two other Nightjar recordings this evening:

XC484858

XC484860

recordings.loc: Suffolk Coastal District (near  Dunwich), Suffolk, England
recordings.rmk:
Habitat. Sandy Heathland (heather, gorse, birch trees)
Nightjar seen and heard flying as sun was setting. This recording was after the sun had set and too dark to then continue seeing birds.
Stonecurlew call is at 1:53
Other sounds of note are the regular shouting of a muntjac and the occassional buzzing of mosquitos (only I don't think I can list them as background species! )
Male churring intermittently, changing song perches by flying in between. Flight perches circa 100 metres apart in a triangle.
At least 3 calling males at the site, recording of the nearest one.

Song plus the warble when it moved off at the end and I think a wing clap mixed in with it.
